questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
All users are assigned Microsoft 365 E5 licenses.
The users receive email messages that appear to come from managers at the company. However, the messages are not from the managers and often include links to malicious websites.
You need to provide a solution to protect the mailboxes of the managers and to inform the users when phishing occurs.
Which two settings should you modify in the anti-phishing policy? To answer, select the appropriate settings in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: on exam 11-27-21
correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant and the devices shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You plan to implement sensitivity labels for users to apply to email messages.
Which Microsoft Outlook versions will support sensitivity labels without requiring additional software?

choices.C: Outlook 2019, Outlook 2016 for Mac, Outlook for iOS, and Outlook on the web
choices.D: Outlook for iOS and Outlook on the web only
choices.A: Outlook 2019 and Outlook on the web only

discussion.content: To use sensitivity labels that are built into Office desktop apps for Windows and Mac, you must use a subscription edition of Office. This labeling client doesn't support standalone editions of Office, such as Office 2016 or Office 2019.

Selected Answer: C
I find it bizarre that it can only be D: Outlook for iOS and Outlook on the web only..
C is correct answer

To use aensitivity labels that are built into Office desktop apps for Windows and Mac, you must use a subscription edition of Office. So Answer A is correct - Outlook Web and for iOS does need additional subscription.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/about-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: C
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/apply-sensitivity-labels-to-your-files-and-email-in-office-2f96e7cd-d5a4-403b-8bd7-4cc636bae0f9#OfficeVersion=Web

comments.content: Sorry I think Answer should be C

discussion.content: Answer should be Outlook on Web Only
04/16/2022 - on the exam
On the exam 11/02/2022
Answer is correct, because sensitivity labels can only be used in M365 apps, but not in Office 2016/2019
Answer C :https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?view=o365-worldwide
On the test Nov 3,2021

comments.content:
D is correct:

Labeling client for desktop apps
To use sensitivity labels that are built into Office desktop apps for Windows and Mac, you must use a subscription edition of Office. This labeling client doesn't support standalone editions of Office, such as Office 2016 or Office 2019.

> Detail: Must use subscription Edition 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?view=o365-worldwide#sensitivity-label-capabilities-in-outlook

discussion.content: I think answer is C. Sensitivity labels are supported in all the latest client versions. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/sensitivity-labels-office-apps?view=o365-worldwide#sensitivity-label-capabilities-in-outlook

Answer is correct.

Exchange administrator or Global administrator for configuring forwarding
Global, License, or User admin to assign licenses
Organization Management or Security Administrator role groups for modifying anti-spam policies.

Admin 5 needs Global Administrator permission to assign license, configure email forwarding and mailbox permission
Admin 6 needs Exchange Administrator permission for modifying anti-spam policies
Correct

comments.content: Sorry the given answer is correct. It should be Global Admin and Exchange Admin

discussion.content: Answer should be User Admin and Exchange Admin
Should not assigned "User Admin" for Admin5?

comments.content: It's counter intuitive, but I agree - I have just tested it and the answer is correct, even if it's not truly following principle of least privilege. Since there's only 3 options on the board, and Admin5 needs to be able to manage licenses (req: User Management) and mail forwardng (req: Exchange Management), they will need Global Admin for both. Mailbox permissions and anti-spam can be done with Exchange Management, so that should be fine for Admin6.

For me is given answer correct.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/email/configure-email-forwarding?view=o365-worldwide

You must be an Exchange administrator or Global administrator in Microsoft 365 to do these steps.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant.
You recently hired two new administrators named Admin5 and Admin6.
You need to grant the following permissions to the new administrators:
✑ Admin5 must be able to assign licenses to users.
Admin6 must be able to modify the email SPAM settings of all users.
//IMG//

✑ Admin5 must be able to configure the email forwarding settings of all users.
✑ Admin5 and Admin6 must be able to manage the mailbox permissions of all users.
The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to each user? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: It's correct

comments.content:
I take back. The global settings apply to all users, so it has to be NO.
These settings apply to all users in the organization who are licensed for Defender for Office 365, regardless of whether the users are included in active Safe Links policies or not

discussion.content:
Safe links can be configured for specific users. Answer should be yes.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/set-up-safe-links-policies?view=o365-worldwide

comments.content: I take back. Global settings is for all users without exception

discussion.content: From the given link and my tests I think the answer is yes

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
Several users in the finance department of the company recently accessed unsafe websites by clicking on links in email messages.
Users in the marketing department of the company report that they must be able to access all the links embedded in email messages.
You need to reduce the likelihood of the finance department users accessing unsafe websites. The solution must affect only the finance department users.
Solution: You modify the Global settings Safe Links policy.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: This is a console that no longer exists...MS will still keep questions from the legacy consoles in the test though...smh
Correct

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You manage a Microsoft Exchange Online subscription.
You use Advanced Threat Protection (ATP).
A partner company sends daily invoices to your company. The invoices are always named AdatumInvoice.xlsx.
Some users report that sometimes they cannot find the invoices in their Inbox folder.
You need to identify whether the invoices are identified as malicious by Microsoft 365.
Which two blades should you use? To answer, select the appropriate blades in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
